awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Advanced Metal Anode with Artificial Solid Electrolyte Interphase (SEI) for Rechargeable Lithium Metal Batteries
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to develop an advanced metal anode (AMA) material for rechargeable lithium metal battery focused on meeting the needs of a high energy density, low-cost energy storage system for applications in consumer electronics, electric vehicles, electric planes and renewable energy storage. The project is designed for the growing global lithium battery market, developing the AMA material as a drop-in replacement for the $10 B anode market.  These batteries would enable broader adoption of electric vehicles and renewable energy sources.  
	
This SBIR Phase I project proposes to prepare an anode material utilizing an artificially generated solid electrolyte interphase (SEI). Use of lithium metal as the anode can double the energy density of current lithium batteries; however, state-of-the-art lithium metal thin film anodes have the tendency to form dendritic structures near the interface with repeated cycling, causing performance and safety issues. Based on a new SEI model, the proposed copper-based anode material will have an SEI guiding the deposition of lithium away from the interface with its designed pore structure. Phase I research efforts will focus on: 1) preparing the AMA material with perfectly covered SEI; 2) demonstrating lithium plating and de-plating capabilities of the AMA material with coin half-cell and full-cell cycling tests. In conjunction with appropriate electrolytes and electrodes, the AMA-based coin half-cells will finish 300 cycles at 1 mA/cm2 and 1 mAh/cm2; and the AMA-based coin full-cells will have 100 cycles at no less than 0.2 C rate with 80% capacity retention.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
LiBAMA is developing an advanced metal anode (AMA) with artificial solid electrolyte interphase based on a new concept.  When fully developed, the new anode enables next generation rechargeable lithium metal batteries with energy density improvement of 50% to 100% compared to current lithium-ion batteries with cost reduction of over 30% and fast charge ability. The improved batteries will help overcome major hurdles for wide adoption of electric vehicles and renewable energy sources.

The commercialization of rechargeable lithium metal batteries has been plagued by the tree-shaped growth of lithium dendrites at the anode-separator interface toward the opposite electrode of the battery. The most common way to counter the problem is to use solid electrolyte to block their growth. However, the blocking electrolyte needs be made perfectly for such strategy to work, making scaling up extremely hard. Besides, high pressure is needed to help block the dendrite growth and manage the volume change, making it hard to deploy such batteries in real life.

LiBAMA worked on a new strategy to solve the problem. Instead of trying to block the lithium dendrite growth, the patent-pending AMA technology uses an artificial passivating layer on a 3D porous electrode to guide the lithium growth to the inside of the anode, thus fundamentally solves the decades-old dendrite problem. The phase I project aims to prove the viability of the concept by answering three major concerns regarding the AMA materials and the technology. One is whether lithium can be reversibly deposited into and stripped out of the pores; another one is the stability of the coating structure; the third one is the scalability of the materials.

In the phase I project, LiBAMA successfully prepared the anodes with designed structure: 3D conductive electrodes with artificial passivating layer. The electrodes have shown 500 deposition and stripping cycles with stable voltage profile, demonstrating the stability of the structure as well as reversibility of the process; also roll-by-roll preparation of the anodes has been designed with common process and commercially available low-cost materials. Visual proofs were obtained demonstrating that when a good passivation layer is present, lithium deposition happens inside the pores of the electrode, in contrast to the case that when there is no passivating layer, lithium grows at the interface.  Because lithium deposits in the pores, there is little volume change and there is no need of high pressure for the battery to work. Additional questions have been answered regarding various aspects of the new concept. For example, what are good 3D substrates; what materials are good for the passivation layer; could the electrode be fast charged?

The results of this phase I project exceed the original project goals, indicating that the new technology represents a better strategy to solve the problems plaguing the lithium metal batteries than those utilized in the prior art with solid electrolyte and high pressure.

 


Last Modified: 10/15/2021
Modified by: Wentao Li
